item.description:
Socialism and libertarianism, beyond their doctrines, are also ideals. That both ideals are embraced by millions who otherwise seem to get along quite nicely may, perhaps, suggest that these two socio-political philosophies need not be trapped in a state of fixed polar opposition. If we can escape the constraints of dogma and doctrine the argument might be made that a socialist can value “rugged individualism” and a libertarian need not bury his or her compassion. Are freedom, social flourishing and artistic perspective the exclusive properties of one side or the other? Is the desire for social welfare incompatible with the desire for less government interference? Philosophy is sometimes a display of passionate insights, but these insights can become hardened into inflexible ideals. In this discussion, we will explore examples of how these purportedly opposite philosophies express concrete complementarity.

I think that there a number of elements in Herbert Spencer’s thought, who is generally viewed as the first libertarian, that would probably (or definitely) be rejected by almost all modern day libertarians and clearly by, e.g. followers of Ayn Rand. For example, consider this quote from the Wikipedia article: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Spencer

"While often caricatured as ultra-conservative, Spencer had opposed private property in land, claiming that each person has a latent claim to participate in the use of the earth. He was sympathetic to Georgism, which also took such a view. He called himself "a radical feminist" and advocated the organization of voluntary labor unions as a bulwark against "exploitation by bosses", and favored an economy organized primarily in free worker co-operatives as a replacement for wage-labor."

And many socialists, I believe, have sympathy for some elements of libertarianism. It is natural that this be the case, because fundamentally intellectual desire for “human flourishing” or what Aristotle called eudaimonia is, in my view, transcendent of any ideological viewpoint of politics. And, as such, this discussion concerns the deeper commonalities that unite the spirit of democracy and freedom.
